Comment: The problem is, this can be a Freedom of Religion issue.  The law requires clergy to report abuse - even if it is revealed to them in the Confessional. They can refuse to give absolution unless the person gave themselves up to the cops, but they themselves can't report. So this law is effectively interfering in the ritual of Confession, which can be taken as a violation of the separation of Church and State.

Comment: For sure. The Cross is a terrible-reminder turned symbol-of-hope; at least that what it's supposed to mean. So, when someone who claims to believe in it hurts or misguides another (especially in such a depraved way), not only are they hurting that first person, they are leading themselves away from it as well. It doesn't change the meaning of the Cross itself, but now their wrongdoing is associated with it in the mind of that first person.       I'm not here to try and change your mind, but if it helps, know that "sin", as an action, just means "to miss the mark". It's an old archery term, and that's how it's meant to be used in relation to Christianity.       That "missing the mark" is going to look different for different people; most are accidental, too many are deliberate. But all of them fall short of the correct target. That's all.       Anyway, take care!
